summary: This is a submission (Submission Number Five) by Adrian Praljak to the Royal Commission, alleging fraud and other offenses by Mikayla Brier-Mills. The author claims Brier-Mills, a law student at Bond University, failed to complete paid work and repay loans, and raises concerns about tax evasion and professional conduct. The document includes transaction records, references to police reports, and debt collection efforts.

persons.name: Adrian Praljak
persons.context: Author of the submission to the Royal Commission. He alleges that Mikayla Brier-Mills defrauded him by taking money for legal/administrative work and loans which she did not repay or complete.

persons.name: Mikayla Brier-Mills
persons.context: A law student at Bond University accused by Adrian Praljak of fraud, theft, failing to complete paid work, not repaying loans, and potential tax evasion.

persons.name: Ronald Sackville
persons.context: The recipient of the submission, addressed as "The Hon Ronald Sackville AO QC Chair of the Royal Commission."

persons.name: Alexander Andrew Tees
persons.context: Described as the Principal of Legal Exchange Lawyers, for whom Adrian Praljak worked as a lawyer/solicitor running the Queensland offices.

persons.name: Adam Packer
persons.context: National Manager of ServeDoc (a process server/debt collector), who provided email correspondence related to Praljak's case.

persons.name: Maneesha Marzol
persons.context: Office Manager at Marzol Holloway & Associates, who sent a debt collection email to Mikayla Brier-Mills on behalf of Adrian Praljak.

connections.description: Praljak outsourced administrative, research, and tutoring work to Brier-Mills, a law student, and provided her with loans. The relationship soured over allegations of non-payment and incomplete work.
Praljak worked as a lawyer/solicitor for Legal Exchange Lawyers, with Tees as his Principal.
Marzol, as office manager for a law firm, acted on Praljak's behalf in attempting to recover debt from Brier-Mills.
Brier-Mills is identified as a law student at Bond University. Praljak raises concerns about potential conflicts of interest with the university.

events.title: Employment and Alleged Fraud Period
events.description: The period during which Adrian Praljak employed Mikayla Brier-Mills for various tasks and provided her loans, leading to the alleged fraud and non-repayment.

events.title: ACORN Report Filed
events.description: Adrian Praljak successfully submitted an online ACORN report (reference CIRS-20190723-30) against Mikayla Brier-Mills for fraud and financial crimes. The matter was referred to QLD Police.

events.title: Debt Collection Email Sent
events.description: Maneesha Marzol, on behalf of Adrian Praljak, sent an email to Mikayla Brier-Mills demanding repayment of a $1050 debt.

events.title: Submission to Royal Commission
events.description: Adrian Praljak sent "Submission Number Five" to the Royal Commission, detailing his allegations against Mikayla Brier-Mills and requesting assistance in recovering his money.

keyFacts: Adrian Praljak alleges Mikayla Brier-Mills, a Bond University law student, committed fraud by accepting payment for work and loans totaling thousands of dollars which she did not complete or repay.
The Commonwealth Bank attempted a "Trace and Recovery" for transactions from Praljak's account to Brier-Mills's ANZ account, but she rejected the request to repay.
An ACORN cybercrime report was filed against Brier-Mills in July 2019 (CIRS-20190723-30) and referred to QLD Police.
Praljak raises serious questions about Brier-Mills's professional conduct, tax compliance, and fitness to practice law in Australia or other jurisdictions.
The submission includes detailed transaction records from 2016-2017 and correspondence from debt collection services (ServeDoc) and a law firm (Marzol Holloway & Associates).
